I mean, it's paint, it's canvas. It's the stuff that you

Same with sculpture. Stone, steel, mud, bricks,

So the question then is,
what's the medium for film

The camera, exactly. That's kind of the brush. I mean, not exactly, but

But what else? What are the other

Others?

So the actual what

But there are lots

useful and interesting in just

thinking about what you do as
a filmmaker or a video maker, and I'm going to use those
terms interchangeably,

as I said on Wednesday, are
what we call or it can be called the plastic elements of film.

And by that, I just
mean the elements that you as the artist, the
filmmaker have control over

and that you can change at will. So the camera. What you choose to do with the
camera is, obviously, extremely

important and in fact
central to the outcome and to what you want to do as
an artist or as a documentarian.

Lighting, again. Whether you're actually adding
lights, setting up lights, doing very complex
lighting setups

and before everyone

And so that is, again,
a plastic element. But there are others too. Can you think of others?

The lens, yeah. What lens you use to
shoot with, exactly. Others?

Yeah, exactly. The scene, the setting. Could be the location. Another way of
thinking about it.

So if you're doing-- and that's
obviously true of a fiction film, but it's also
true of a documentary. If you're interviewing somebody,
where do you choose to put them

and what does where
you choose to put them say about your subject? What do you want it to say? You have control over
that and you have--

in a lot of ways, you have
as much or as little control as you want, because you
can be very interventionist

and place them exactly where
you want them or you can just do whatever happens.

If you went to interview
a professor here at MIT and you found them

it right there.

That's another thing. So if you think

Props, how you arrange

how you edit a piece. So there are any number-- and these are just a few.

Any number of plastic
elements that you can control, and I think this is just

So today, we're going
to talk about camera, which is in many ways, first and
foremost, the plastic element.

It's the first one that was
mentioned here when I asked you about what kinds of
things you use as a tool,

and it's obviously
the fundamental thing, because everything is
passing through the lens.

And I want to just provide a
very, very brief introduction to some of the really basic
ideas in filmmaking, which

are very similar in many ways
to some of the basic ideas in still photography

And one way to think about them,
one way I like to think about them are as the four F's.

F-stop, or exposure, focus,
focal length, and framing.

And there are others, but
they don't start with F, but I like to start with these.

And F-stop is also
maybe a bit simplistic when you're talking

F-stop, focus, focal
length, framing. And I'm just going to spend a

and don't expect to
absorb it all right now. It's the kind of
thing that's going to make a lot more sense

So I'm not going to get really
hung up on a lot of details. This isn't a class on
optics or the physics

of light or anything
like that, but I want to just introduce
a couple of terms. So first, exposure.

F-stop or aperture is one
of the basic things that controls what your
exposure of your camera is,

and that is basically
in simplistic terms or in simple terms how much
light is entering the camera

lens. How much light is
hitting the sensor that's recording the image?

And lenses are equipped with
an aperture that is adjustable. So you see at the
top there, there's

an aperture that's very
wide, it's very open, which in terms of F-stop
is a very low number, F2,

and at the bottom of
that very same lens, the aperture is almost
completely shut. It's just almost a pinhole,
and that corresponds

to a very high F, number F22. And lenses, you'll see that
the lenses on our cameras

can be adjusted. You can either leave
it in auto and let the camera choose what
the exposure should be,

or you can choose it. And obviously,
the more light you have in a scene, the more
stop down or the smaller

the aperture would be in order
to get the correct exposure. In other words, in order to
have enough light hitting

your sensor but
not too much light in order to get a
good looking image.

Just also quickly, F-stop
is not the only way

to adjust exposure. You do have other controls. You have the shutter speed. The shutter speed is basically
determining how much time

each frame of your
video or your film is exposed to light
as it goes by.

And you can adjust it, but
in this video and film,

you normally aren't
going to adjust it. You normally want to keep it
for normal appearing motion

at about 1/60 of a second. So in practical
terms, unless you're shooting something
that's a very high speed

activity or some kind
of special situation or you're maybe in a very,
very low light situation,

you don't want to use the
shutter as an exposure control. Mainly, you're going
to keep it at 160.

Yes, sir? TA: It's usually
double the frame rate. So if it's like if you're
shooting 24 frames per second,

it would be 1 over 48. PROFESSOR: Right, and we're
shooting 30 frames per second, so that's why it's 160, yeah.

The second thing is the
camera sensitivity itself. Different cameras have a

and you'll very quickly come to
both appreciate and hate some

of the quirks of our camera. It is sensitive compared
to some and not as others,

so it depends on what
you may be expecting. You can also, however, there
are adjustments to cameras

and video cameras basically. It's called the gain control. So if the lighting
situation is very poor,

you don't have a lot of
light, the gain can be raised. But the trade off is that the
image gets very, very fuzzy.

Much lower resolution. But there is that sensitivity. And then finally, of
course, there are lights.

You can add light. Either by changing the
location, going from--

if one room is too dark and

you can add them.

We actually are--

to overcome that clip

lights, regular consumer

to control exposure, the essential basic one
is the F stopper aperture.

So let's go on to focus, the
second F. First thing to know is that just like with
exposure, this camera and almost

all video cameras have two
settings, auto and manual. Manual focus is almost always
preferred, because just as

with exposure, the auto
setting can be fooled. It will breathe, so
it'll change its mind

and focus on something else
in the middle of a shot which can be very distracting
and annoying. So in almost all
situations you're

going to want to stay manual,
both for F-stop and for focus. But you do have that option.

You do have auto as
a choice, and there are situations, where
it's better to be on auto

than to be nothing, right? I mean, if you grab the camera
because there's a flying saucer

landing outside and you want to
get the shot, if it's an auto, it's much better to have
something than to have nothing

and to be adjusting. But generally, we discourage
the use of auto focus and auto

iris. Second thing to think about with
focus is the depth of field.

Depth of field is
basically a term that refers to how much of your
image in terms of the depth

is in focus? So if you're shooting
me sitting here talking as our camera person
is, hopefully, I'm in focus.

The background behind me
doesn't have to be in focus, and it might or
might not be in focus

depending on the aperture
that the camera is set up. So a very wide aperture because
it's a low light situation

means that you have
very shallow focus, and the background
may be out of focus. The smaller the aperture
gets, the deeper your focus

is so that the background
suddenly could become in focus. And this is something that you
can-- it's an aesthetic choice.

It's not just determined
by your lighting, although that's
obviously something you have to deal with, but
you can actually make choices

about what's in focus and what's
not, and how deep the focus is and in it and it has an
impact on how people read

the images that you create. I don't if anybody
here is nearsighted, but if you want to get a
sense of how depth of field

is determined by the aperture,
you can take your glasses off, and you can actually do this.

And the smaller you
make the pinhole that you're looking through,
the more in focus you are

or what you're seeing is. And it doesn't really work
if you're everything's always in focus for you.

But for me, it
works really well. So if I don't have my glasses in
the morning, I can look at you

and I can see that
you're quite sharp if I make the pinhole small enough. So anyway, it's kind
of a cool effect.

And it gives you a sense that,
basically, what's happening is that the smaller the aperture
that the light is passing

through, the more aligned,
and again, this is not an optics class and I'm not
going to go too far down

this road that I
don't know much about, but the light is more
aligned, there's less scatter,

and that makes everything
in sharper focus. So again, focus is something
that is extremely important.

So is exposure. They're non-negotiable. The first two F's are, either
you did it or you didn't.

You're either in
focus or you're not. And you pretty much
want to be in focus and you pretty much want
to be properly exposed.

You don't want to have too
much light hitting your image, you don't want to
have too little.

Even if you want to manipulate
focus or exposure later because you want to actually
have things appear out

of focus, it's much
better to do it in editing and
post-production than to do it when you're shooting, because
you can't change it back.

You can't make a
blurry image sharp. You can make a
sharp image blurry. You can take a very
well exposed image

and make it dark or bright,
but you can't very easily take a dark image and
make it properly exposed.

So these first two,
as I said, I usually refer to them as the
non-negotiable two.

The next two, however,
are infinitely negotiable.

Focal length refers
to whether you're shooting something
in a wide angle

or a telephoto or
a normal setting. And again, you may
have some experience

with still photography. Wide angle lens
are the lenses that

are a smaller number
of millimeters, like the 12 millimeter lens,
the 6 millimeter lens, the 16
millimeter lens. Telephoto are the big numbers. 200, 300, and 150.

And each of them give you very,
very, very different feeling

kinds of images. The wide angle lens gives
you a much wider angle of view, obviously.

So if you're filming
landscapes, you can put a wide angle
lens on your camera,

and from the same position,
get a much wider field. It also gives you
much deeper focus.

To go back to the idea of depth
of field, with a wide angle lens, it's much easier to
get everything in focus

from the foreground
to the background. Telephoto lenses,
on the other hand, are a much narrower
angle of view.

So if I'm standing in the same
place filming the same thing, I'm seeing a much
narrower field,

which can also be thought
of as magnification, right? So same image, but now, if I'm
filming the camera person who's

filming me, I'm
seeing just his face instead of the whole field.

And the focus, the depth of
field, is much shallower. So it's much easier to
get a nice soft background on a telephoto lens.

Just one other note
about focal length. Again, it's something that
is infinitely variable

and you can choose
as a filmmaker what kinds of focal lengths
you use, but don't confuse

a wide angle lens with a
wide shot or a telephoto lens with a close up. It's easier to get a close
up with a telephoto lens

and it's easier to get a wide
shot with a wide angle lens, but it's certainly possible to
do a wide shot with a telephoto

lens. You just have to be much farther
away from your subject and vise versa. It's very possible to do a
close up with a wide angle lens,

you just have to
get much closer. But they'll feel
very, very different, and I'll show you some extreme
examples here in a minute.

So this is an extreme
wide angle lens. What we call a fish eye lens. And you'll see, first of all,
that it's very distorted,

but you're seeing a very,
very wide field of view. So wide, in fact, that the
only way to accommodate is the distortion.

You're also seeing
incredible depth of field. The background, the
infinite distance is sharp, and so is
the hand that's not

that far away from the camera. It also wide angle lenses--
and this is an extreme example.

Wide angle lenses tend
to distort and elongate the distance between objects.

So that hand is much closer to
the camera than it might appear and the distance between the
hand and every other element

going back is
somewhat elongated. So it makes smaller
rooms feel much bigger,

it makes distances
seem much greater.  Telephoto lens.

The long lens, because
they're long, do the opposite. So here, we have a
telephoto shot of a bird,

and you see first of all that
the background is very, very soft, even though it's not that
far really behind the bird,

and things are very compressed. So the distance between
the bird and the background

feels like there's not
much distance at all, even though there might
actually be quite a lot.

One of the things
about telephoto lenses is that sometimes
the depth of field is so shallow that
you can literally

have the eye of the bird in
focus and the background that

of the plant that it's standing
on completely soft here. The plant is actually in focus.

But if you're
doing an interview, a human eye might be
in focus and their ear might be out of focus at
an extreme telephoto lens.

So this is actually
aesthetically really pleasing, because the foreground
jumps out at you.

Our eye goes
immediately to the bird and the background
just drops off into this very soft,
nice backplate.

So again, I could shoot
a wide shot like this, but it would look
extremely different

than shooting a wide shot
with a wide angle lens.

So now, let's talk
about framing. And framing, this is really--

once you master the basics
of the camera framing is a catchall term for
everything else about how

you choose to shoot things. Do you choose to
shoot close ups? Do you shoot choose
to shoot wide shots?

What's the grammar of film? And we're not going to do
any kind of exhaustive talk

about that right now,
but it's an infinitely interesting and
inexhaustible subject.

Sabrina, you mentioned
that on Wednesday night, when we were looking at
those very early films, everything was
filmed head to toe.

And that was because
I mean there really hadn't been a grammar of
film developed at that point. They were just thinking
about them as stage plays.

So people would walk in head to
toe and they'd do their thing and they'd walk out. But a few years
after that, people

started filming close ups, and
that was a huge revolution. They started filming shots
of the hands of people

doing things. They started moving
the camera so that it would pan from one
person to another and back.

They started filming
shots with someone in the foreground and
someone in the background, and then they'd do a
reverse with this person

in the foreground and this
person in the background. And that kind of opened up this
whole language that all of us--

we're used to reading this
language because we've been doing it our entire
lives, but at that point, it was an extremely new.

What shot works with this shot? What's confusing,
what's not confusing? How do we understand a scene?

And all of that is
related to framing. So we're going to be looking at
a lot of films in this class.

We're going to be talking about
why they were shot the way they were shot, both in terms
of the social terms

and the technical terms,
the technological terms, but also in terms of the
framing and the grammar of them.

And it's something
that you're going to gain a lot of experience
and understanding
of as you make your own films.

But just for starters, I'm going
to talk a little bit about just

some basic ideas and concepts
that you might want to think about as you frame a scene.

Let's take this
class, for instance. How would I film this class?

There are an infinite number
of ways that I could do it. It's being filmed right now
for a very particular reason.

A very particular purpose,
OpenCourseWare is filming it, and the way they're

I'm the one talking

and on the slides,
because it's information that they're trying to capture.

If we were filming it

documentary cinema verite

direct cinema style, which is if

we could use a handheld
camera, that camera could be completely mobile.

If I'm not what's

Maybe it's a film about you
and they're following you in your day and I'm
just this droning

voice in the background. What they're interested

how to capture that.

So it'd be completely
different way of filming this and the

would be completely
different than what we're doing right now. We could film it with

We could film as we

pointing at students,

camera in the background,
we can edit it together. How we shoot people,
whether we're shooting them

in close ups or wide shots all
has a really significant impact on the story that we're telling.

And one of the things
with documentary film is that as a camera
person, again,

let's say that we're doing a
day in the life of Sabrina. As the story unfolds, we're
constantly making adjustments.

We're constantly making new
choices about what to film. So if we're filming
your experience

of being in this class, as that
experience changes as a camera person, the camera
person would need

to be sensitive to that change. So let's say you got into a

with Dave, our TA. Because you didn't agree
with his interpretation of something, which will happen.

No, no. So suddenly, we would
be focusing on Dave

you listening to Dave, looking

unhappy, arguing back. Suddenly, we're on Dave, Dave

back and forth, and

I'm not even in the picture. It doesn't matter what I'm

Then we're the
camera person starts looking for up reaction

So we touched on the idea

in the documentary film. What you choose to frame

So you can walk into that
situation I just described and film it with
an agenda, like we

want to make Sabrina

in a certain way,

or we want to show how

film it in a different way. Or you could be very sensitive

and adjust and try to be make an

But generally, we do go in

So anyway, that's
the overall thing. We're not going to talk
about a lot of film grammar right now because I could go
on for the rest of the time

and I'd rather get on to
the actual camera work. But I am going to-- I am going to just raise a
couple of things to think about

since you very soon have
cameras in your hands and just basic kinds of
things to think about

as you choose the shots
that you're going to film.

First of all, there's
a real tendency when you get a camera for the
first time-- and I mean,

I'm sure everyone at this
point is filmed something with a video camera. There's a real tendency to
want to capture everything.

So we're in this room, we're
filming, and you think, oh, I'm going to get
everything, and you

start doing this, which is
basically moving continually, because that's how
our eyes work, right?

I'm just looking around,
I see everything. So you just assume the
camera works that way, too.

But what you end up doing
is capturing nothing, because with the camera you have
to fake the way your eye works,

and the way your eye
works is I'm doing this and I'm seeing everything,
but I'm also continuously--

my brain is continuously
picking out things and making close
ups out of the stuff

that I see making
different angles. So when I was talking
about suddenly there was a close up of
even though I saw everything

else too. When I talked about
Dave, suddenly there was a close up of
Dave in my head, right?

So the camera has
to do that, and you have to make it do
that, which means that what they call hosing
down the room, which

is this continual I don't
want to miss anything so I'm just going
to keep doing this,

it just ends up with mush. And you're not telling a
story and you're not really getting any shots that
you're able to edit.

So you want to be deliberate
about what you're shooting and you want to think
about what you're shooting.

What story am I
telling and what images do I need to tell that story?

Do I need to focus on you? Do I need to focus on Dave? Do I need to shoot a wide
shot that establishes

the geography of
the room so that I know where people are sitting. Second thing is
very basic thing.

Hold your shots. There's also a tendency
that goes along with this hosing down the
room to never really hold

on anything. So I'm filming Sabrina,
but then suddenly, I

want to go over here and
then I want to go back, and then I end up
with nothing again.

So you we want to make a choice
and then stick with it for long enough that you
actually get something.

So if I'm shooting
a close up of Chris listening to me
skeptically, I want to hold on for a certain
number of seconds

and then go back to the next
thing that I want to shoot. And it can be hard sometimes,
because suddenly, something really interesting is
happening over there

and you want to run
over and get it, and you need to be responsive
to that and obviously pay attention to it.

But if you get too
caught up in the moment, you end up with
nothing, and this is something that is
a real struggle even

for professional camera
people sometimes, because they have all of this
information bombarding them

maybe don't hold the
shots long enough. There's kind of a rule of the
nice long, slow count to 10

before you then pan
away to something else. Could be count to five if the
action is a little faster.

But just remember, frame
something up, hold the shot, and then move on.

And then the idea also when
you're moving the camera is think about why
you're moving the camera.

Why would you move
the camera rather than just to hose down the room?
OK, any basic ideas?  Well, if I'm moving--

if I have a camera, why would
I actually start doing this? Why would I actually move?

Well, compared to just moving
like this randomly or not

moving at all. What would motivate me to
move the camera around?

Right. Yeah, exactly. So following an action. And it might be actually
a physical action.

I mean, if I'm profiling
Chris and suddenly she gets up and goes over to
really getting Dave's face

to really argue
with them, I would want to follow them, right? But if they're just
talking even cordially,

I don't know why I always
bring you to conflict, David. I don't-- TA: It's just who I am.

PROFESSOR: Yeah, you just
draw it out of people. But even if they're just
they're speaking, as you say,

I would be panning
back and forth. And at some point, I might
come over here and film Dave

and start filming from

is-- it's going to make a
